Here $V_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}}$ is a normalisation constant that ensures $\int_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}}  \ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{{\hat{\rho}}}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace  \ud{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace} = 1 $.

We can take this approach further by observing that any Wigner function is mathematically equivalent to a scalar potential field~\cite{KF-Flow} so that we can derive from it a vector field that we term the ``Wigner flow'' according to $\vec{\mathcal{W}}_{{\hat{\rho}}}({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace})=-\nabla_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}}\ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{{\hat{\rho}}}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace$.

\begin{abstract}
The possibility of constructing a complete, continuous Wigner function for any quantum system has been a subject of investigation for over 50 years. 
A key system that has served to illustrate the difficulties of this problem has been an ensemble of spins. 
While numerous attempts have come close to generating a complete Wigner phase-space description, each has either being artificial in its construction or fallen short of realising this ambition. 
Here we present  a natural method of constructing Wigner functions that can be used to fully describe any quantum object or systems of systems. 
We see no reason why our approach should be limited to non-relativistic quantum mechanics; it may even lead to phase-space methods for more exotic frameworks such as string theory. 
In addition we show that the natural visual representation of the quantum state by the Wigner function leads to multiple and intuitive entanglement measures.
\end{abstract}

\keywords{characteristic functions, entanglement, group parametrizations}

\maketitle





Out of all available choices, one can argue that the Wigner function presents the most natural phase-space representation of quantum mechanics.
 The main advantage being that it simultaneously retains the intuitiveness with respect to classical phase-space whilst rendering clearly quantum information - leading to the now iconic Wigner function for macroscopically distinct superposition of states (Schr\"odinger cat states)~\cite{Deleglise:2008gt}. 
In this regard the Wigner function possesses a unique advantage over other representations (such as the $P$~\cite{PhysRevLett.10.277,PhysRev.131.2766} and $Q$~\cite{Husimi1940} functions). 
Even though all are quasi-probability distribution functions, the Wigner function's marginals are easily linked to amplitudes of a given representation, and its equations of motion are closely and intuitively relatable to the classical ones for the same system~\cite{Wigner1984}.
These properties are further augmented by a transparent connection to the quantum-classical transition where solutions to the classical Liouville equation can be recovered as the action becomes large with respect to a Plank cell (see, e.g.,~\cite{PhysRevLett.80.4361}). 
Indeed, it is possible to reformulate much of quantum mechanics in phase-space (a nice historical overview can be found in~\cite{Curtright:2012ka}). 
Feynman's path integrals and the Wigner/Weyl/Groenewold/Moyal phase-space approach share a similar ambition; to have a formulation of quantum mechanics with a clear and intuitive link to classical physics. 
They also have a number of features in common where, e.g., they both are underpinned by a statistical ensemble view (in the Feynman picture we sum over paths and Wigner functions are analogous to classical probability density functions), it is even possible to link the two~\cite{Samson:2003ij}. 

So, if this representation is so good - why has it not become much more popular (as the Feynman path integral did). 
One possible reason is that the Wigner function is not directly comparable to a classical probability density function as it can take on negative values. 
However, this negativity is associated with quantumness and vanishes in the classical limit. 
Given that physicists have historically been able to overcome such ontological difficulties when a model has shown to add value, we do not see this as an obstacle to moving to a phase-space formulation of quantum mechanics (for an extended discussion see, e.g.,~\cite{extended_probabilities}).  
Of much greater importance is the fact that finding a Wigner function for finite dimensional systems (and systems of these systems) has proved challenging. 
Wigner functions that are themselves discrete can be developed with nice properties~\cite{Wootters19871,PhysRevA.70.062101}, but they lack the intuitiveness of their continuous variable counterparts. 
There has also been some progress with regards to the development of continuous Wigner-like functions for finite dimensional systems - especially with regards to ensembles of spins~\cite{Agarwal1981,Shibata1976,PhysRevA.59.971,Braunstein-1004.5425,Klimov-1008.2920,Wolf6247,Luis-052112,Luis-495302,Klimov055303,TilmaKae1,PhysRevA.86.062117}. 
However, each has come with their own limitations; the most important of these being that the Wigner function must be a complete representation of any quantum state (e.g., one should be able to reconstruct the state vector/density operator from the Wigner function itself, at least up to an arbitrary total phase). 
Previous work produced Wigner functions that either failed to be complete; were artificial in their construction; or did not address experimentally realisable systems. 
Based on the normal Wigner function for continuous variable systems we propose an alternative method for computing Wigner functions that addresses this issue - providing a pathway to the formulation of intuitively analogous, easy to calculate, complete Wigner functions for quantum systems that are currently of importance to both quantum information and atomic/molecular/optical physics.

The standard textbook form of  the Wigner function describing how to transform a Hilbert space operator $\OpA$ to a classical phase-space function $\mathrm{A}(\mathbf{q},\mathbf{p})$~\cite{Weyl1927,Moyal1949,Ozizmir1967,Leaf1968-1,Leaf1968-2}, is
\bel{Weyl-Wigner-ND1}
\mathrm{A}(\mathbf{q},\mathbf{p}) = \int_{-\boldsymbol{\infty}}^{+\boldsymbol{\infty}} \ud \mathbf{z} \, \bra{\mathbf{q}+\frac{\mathbf{z}}{2}} \hat{A} \ket{\mathbf{q}-\frac{\mathbf{z}}{2}} \, e^{i \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{z}/\hbar}, 
\ee where $\mathbf{q}=[q_1,q_2,\ldots,q_N]$ and $\mathbf{p}=[p_1,p_2,\ldots,p_N]$ are $N$-dimensional vectors representing classical phase-space position and momentum values, $\mathbf{z}=[z_1,z_2,\ldots,z_N]$, and $\hbar$ is Planck's constant. 
It is well known that this can be also written in terms of the displacement ($\OpD$) and parity (${\ensuremath{\hat \Pi}\xspace}$) operators  according to:
\bel{WignerStart}
\mathrm{A}({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace})=2 \Trace{ \hat{A} \, \OpD({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}) {\ensuremath{\hat \Pi}\xspace} \OpD^\dag({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}) }
\ee
where ${\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}$ is any full parametrisation of the phase-space.
In this situation, the displacement operator is often parametrised in terms of position and momentum coordinates or eigenvalues of the annihilation operators (coherent states).
Furthermore, this Wigner function is nothing more than the expectation value of the displaced parity operator. 
The question then, is, especially for composite quantum systems, \emph{can this displaced parity operators approach be generalised to other, especially spin, systems?}
The starting point, which shares the same form as~\Eq{WignerStart}, is to observe that any phase-space distribution for $\OpA$ is a characteristic function $\ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{\OpA}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace$ given in terms of a 
``characteristing'' operator $\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace$ parametrized in terms of a set of phase-space coordinates ${\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}$ and $\OpA$ for the system according to the generalized Weyl rule that maps operators to functions according to 
\bel{WignerBaseDef}
\ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{\OpA}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace=\Trace{\OpA \, \ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace}.
\ee
Such a distribution function is said to have a Stratonovich-Weyl correspondence~\cite{Stratonovich56} with the operator if it satisfies certain properties (note that the special case $\OpA={\hat{\rho}}$ yields a distribution function for the state of the quantum system). Setting ${\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}({{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}})}\xspace}=2\OpD({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}) {\ensuremath{\hat \Pi}\xspace} \OpD({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace})$ yields the usual Wigner function in position and momentum space.

Based on work by Moyal \textit{et.\ al.\ }\cite{Moyal1949,Wigner1984,Varilly:1989gs}, C. Brif and A. Mann~\cite{PhysRevA.59.971} used this approach to propose  a general method to generate phase-space distributions and the concomitant calculus needed to formulate quantum mechanics of which Wigner functions arise as a special case of more general characteristic functions. 
Results from~\cite{Wigner1984} (especially section 4.4) and ~\cite{PhysRevA.59.971,OCONNELL1981121} can then be brought to bear in order to formulate specific Wigner functions. 
This approach has been most successfully applied in~\cite{Klimov-1008.2920} but the construction of the Wigner function for a system of spins required a somewhat artificial mapping to a multipole expansion.

How do we improve on this? As with past works, to generate a Wigner function, $\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace$ must be that operator which satisfies the Stratonovich-Weyl correspondence and that is self conjugate. 
While this statement is true it does not capture the essence of~\Eq{WignerStart} where the Wigner function of a quantum state is also (twice) the expectation value of the displaced parity operator. 
Now, the parity operator can be thought of as one that produces a $\pi$ rotation in phase-space. 
In this way {\ensuremath{\hat \Pi}\xspace} has analogous properties to $\hat{\sigma}_z$ for a two-level quantum system in the Pauli representation where it acts as a $\pi$ rotation about the $z$-axis of the Bloch sphere.
In this way, the rotation operator, $\OpU_2^\Half(\theta,\phi,\Phi)=e^{\ui \hat{\sigma}_z \phi}e^{\ui \hat{\sigma}_y \theta}e^{\ui \hat{\sigma}_z \Phi}$, can also be thought of as being analogous to the displacement operator. 
So, in order to obtain a Wigner function for a two-level atom/qubit/spin we are motivated to think of replacing the displaced parity operator with the rotated $\sigma_z$ operator and impose the self conjugate Stratonovich-Weyl correspondence.

This argument leads to the following expression
\bel{eq:WF1s}
{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace} _2^\Half(\theta,\phi)=\Half \left[\Id -\sqrt{3}\left(\OpU_2^\Half \hat{\sigma}_z\OpU_2^\Half\right) \right]
\ee
where the Euler angles $(\theta,\phi)$ are being used to parametrise phase-space.  
The difference in form to~\Eq{WignerStart} is needed to ensure that~\Eq{eq:WF1s} produces a Wigner function with the correct properties under the Stratonovich-Weyl correspondence in phase-space. 

We can use~\Eq{eq:WF1s} as a starting point for constructing \ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace for more complex spin systems and ensembles of spins. 
Crucially, we need to observe that a set of $D$ general spin systems live in a Hilbert space of the form $\bigotimes_1^D \SU{2}$ that is a subspace of $\SU{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}}$ where {\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace} is the total dimension of the system. 
From this, the key to formulating an appropriate kernel is observing that  the operator that plays the same role as the parity operator needs to belong the Hilbert space of the total system, which is $\SU{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}}$. 
This ``parity'' operator is the last of the generalised Gell-Mann matrices, $\hat{\Lambda}_i$,  which, as $\hat{\sigma}_z$ is $\hat{\Lambda}_{3}$ in  $\SU{2}$, is a natural extension of the case considered in~\Eq{eq:WF1s}. 
This observation leads us to propose that spin Wigner functions can be generated using kernels of the form:
\bel{eq:WFNs}
\ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace=\frac{1}{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}} \left[\Id_{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}} -\mathcal{N}\left(\hat{\mathbb{U}}({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}) \hat{\Lambda}_{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}^2-1}\hat{\mathbb{U}}^\dag({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}) \right) \right]
\ee
where $\hat{\mathbb{U}}$ is some appropriate rotation operator, or product of operators, closed under {\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace} (while we focus on continuous {\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace} our definiton could work in the discrete case too); $\mathcal{N}$ is a normalisation factor depending on $\hat{\mathbb{U}}$; and $\hat{\Lambda}_{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}^2-1}$ is a diagonal matrix where every non-zero element is $\sqrt{\frac{2}{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}({\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}-1)}}$ except $(\hat{\Lambda}_{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}^2-1})_{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace} {\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}}=-\sqrt{\frac{2({\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}-1)}{{\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}}}$~\cite{Tilma2}.  
The question we now address is how to choose $\hat{\mathbb{U}}$ so as to satisfy the self conjugate Stratonovich-Weyl correspondence. Our tests to date lead us to believe that this is a general expression that works for any combination of spins which means that we have a pathway to generating Wigner functions for fermions, bosons, any other finite dimensional system and arbitrary combinations of each. 

From this one framework, there are a number of different possible ``true'' Wigner functions we can now develop to address different situations and needs. 
We now introduce the ones that we have explored so far. 
The first example is a spin-$j$ representation of \SU{2}. 
Here $\hat{\mathbb{U}}=\OpU^{j}_{2}=e^{\ui \OpJ_3 \phi}e^{\ui \OpJ_2 \theta}e^{\ui \OpJ_3 \Phi}$ where $\OpJ_i$ are the usual angular momentum operators for a space of dimension ${\ensuremath{\mathfrak{D}}\xspace}=2j+1$ (where $j$ is $0,1/2,1,3/2,\ldots$). In this case 
\bel{highj}
\hat{\Delta}_2^j(\theta,\phi)=\frac{1}{2j+1}
\left[
	\Id_{2j+1} +
	\mathcal{N}
	\OpU^{j}_{2}
	\hat{\Lambda}_{(2j+1)^2-1}
	(\OpU^{j}_{2})^\dag
\right]
\ee 
where $\mathcal{N}=\sqrt{{(2j+2)(2j+1)(2j)}/{2}}$ and we note that $\Phi$ makes no contribution.

In~\Fig{fig:egs} (a-c) we present plots of these Wigner functions applied to three example superposition states that are spin cat states. 
We could follow previous work, such as~\cite{PhysRevA.49.4101,PhysRevA.86.062117,Klimov-1008.2920}, and map spin coherent states onto this space so as to visualise such systems of two-level atoms (but without the need for a multipole expansion). 
While there is a lot of work using such mappings the Wigner functions can be hard to interpret as a high-spin space does not directly reflect the tensor product structure of a number, $D$, of two level atoms/qubits/spins. 
Instead, we introduce a different  kernel that does recognise this structure by using a different rotation operator $\hat{\mathbb{U}}=\bigotimes_i^D \hat{U}^{\Half}_2(\theta_i,\phi_i,\Phi_i)_i=\bigotimes_i^D e^{\ui \hat{\sigma}_z^{(i)} \phi_i}e^{\ui \hat{\sigma}_y^{{(i)}} \theta_i}e^{\ui \hat{\sigma}_z^{(i)} \Phi_i}$ which is the tensor product of the rotation operator for each spin-$\Half$ system (note that if we used $\hat{S}_i$ instead of $\hat{\sigma}_i$ this would also produce an interesting Wigner function and the difference between the two will be expanded upon in a future publication).
\ba
\Hat{\Delta}_{2\otimes}^\Half(\{\theta_i,\phi_i\})&=&\frac{1}{2^D}
\Bigg[
	\Id_{2^D} + \label{susu} \\ \nonumber &&
	\mathcal{N}
	\left\{\bigotimes_i^D (\OpU^{\Half}_2)_i\right\}
	\hat{\Lambda}_{2^{2D}-1}
	\left\{\bigotimes_i^D (\OpU^{\Half}_2)_i^\dag\right\}
	\Bigg]
\ea 
where $\mathcal{N}=\sqrt{{(2^D+1)(2^D)(2^D-1)}/{2}}$ and we note again that the $\Phi_i$'s make no contribution. 
As the dimension of this Wigner function scales with the number of qubits/atoms/spins it becomes harder to visualise. 
However, the slice that sets all $\theta_i=\theta_j$ and $\phi_i=\phi_j$ for all $i,j$ has good analogy with the $Q$ function.
In~\Fig{fig:egs} (d-f) we show the this slice for all $i,j$ for a selection of states that are usually mapped onto the respective spin states shown in ~\Fig{fig:egs} (a-c). 
It may also be of interest to note that we obtain analytic expressions for all of the Wigner functions plotted here which allows for deeper insights than the graphics alone provide. This, together with the better reflection of the underlying structure of the quantum system, yields a Wigner function that has utility beyond visualisation of quantum states and we will return to discuss this shortly. 

It is intersting to note that if we write $\OpA = \OpV \OpA_0 \OpV^\dag$ where $\OpV$ is some unitary operator then, in general,
\bel{easy}
\ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{\OpA}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace=\Trace{ \OpV \OpA_0 \OpV^\dag \, \ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace}=\Trace{  \OpA_0\, \tilde{\Delta}({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace})},
\ee
where we have a new, "rotated" kernel $\tilde{\Delta}({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace})=\OpV^\dag  \ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace \OpV$.
Then, if, for example $\OpA={\hat{\rho}}$ and $\OpV$ was the evolution operator, or a set of quantum gate operations, this expression can lead  an efficient way to compute the Wigner function for a dynamical process or an algorithm as $\OpV^\dag  \ensuremath{{\ensuremath{\hat{\Delta}}\xspace}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace \OpV$ (a similar process could be used visualise gate operations and algorithms themselves in phase-space).

As an example of the utility of this approach is shown in~\Fig{Fig:sq} where we have applied this approach to a set of spins using $\Hat{\Delta}_{2\otimes}^\Half(\{\theta_i,\phi_i\})$ for a toy model of one-axis twisting. 

Before proceeding, we note that there is a further useful Wigner function example obtained by setting $\hat{\mathbb{U}}=\OpU_N^\Half$ the rotation operator for $\SU{N}$ (as defined in~\cite{Tilma2}). 
This results in the kernel 
\be
\Hat{\Delta}_N^\Half(\{\theta_i,\phi_i\})=\frac{1}{N}
\left[
	\Id_{N} +
	\mathcal{N}
	\OpU_N^\Half
	\hat{\Lambda}_{N^{2}-1}
	(\OpU_N^\Half)^\dag
\right]
\ee
that is needed to generate a Wigner function for a general $N$-level quantum system or qudit, where $\mathcal{N}=\sqrt{{(N+1)(N)(N-1)}/{2}}$.  This function is identical that defined in~\cite{TilmaKae1}  but without explicit reference to coherent states. 
In this case there are $N(N-1)/2$ pairs of coordinates $\{\theta_i,\phi_i\}$ corresponding to every pure state being a coherent state. 
We note that this means that the graphical representation of pure states is not so interesting but instead we could consider the dynamic of a set of $D$ qubits/atoms/spins represented by this function. 
In this way we see that their dynamics can be mapped onto the dynamics of a coherent state in $\SU{N=2^D}$ which is a form of holographic principle that reminds us of conformal field theories. 
We would also like to point out, while it is beyond the scope of this paper, there will be many other useful Wigner functions based on~\Eq{eq:WFNs}, for example, if we use: $\hat{\mathbb{U}}=\hat{U}^{j=0}_2(\theta_s,\phi_s,\Phi_s) \otimes \hat{U}^{j=1/2}_2(\theta_p,\phi_p,\Phi_p)\otimes\hat{U}^{j=1}_2(\theta_d,\phi_d,\Phi_d)\otimes \ldots$ the resulting Wigner function might find great utility in atomic physics as it is a decomposition that naturally reflects atomic orbital structure.

Returning to our main discussion of $\Hat{\Delta}_{2\otimes}^\Half(\{\theta_i,\phi_i\})$, as with all Wigner functions, quantum correlations within the quantum state lead to interference fringes with negative values.

If this function is $\geq 0$ then it quantifies the ``quantumness'' of any given state by measuring the total amount of ``negativity" in the Wigner function. 
Here $V_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}}$ is a normalisation constant that ensures $\int_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}}  \ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{{\hat{\rho}}}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace  \ud{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace} = 1 $.
For $\Hat{\Delta}_{2\otimes}^\Half(\{\theta_i,\phi_i\})$ we find that this provides a form of entanglement measure which, although ordered differently, is equivalent to the von Neumann entropy formalism for pure states (mixed states have been analysed and will be the topic of a future paper).
We can take this approach further by observing that any Wigner function is mathematically equivalent to a scalar potential field~\cite{KF-Flow} so that we can derive from it a vector field that we term the ``Wigner flow'' according to $\vec{\mathcal{W}}_{{\hat{\rho}}}({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace})=-\nabla_{{\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}}\ensuremath{\mathrm{W}_{{{\hat{\rho}}}}\left({\ensuremath{\boldsymbol{\Omega}}\xspace}\right)}\xspace$.
The resultant vector field of the Wigner function lays out the tangent space and shows the ``flow'' of the Wigner function.
This allows us to explore areas such as a Helmholtz decomposition that should allow us to study a field-equation formalism of entanglement that may connect to incompressibility and Lyapunov-like exponents; for example visualizing islands of stable entanglement in collections of noisy quantum spin systems.
